tn.text: They put many blankets on King David to try to keep him warm.
"So the king's servants searched"

tn.ref: within all the borders of Israel
tn.text: This is a generalization. AT: "all over the land of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This is a woman's name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
a person from the city of Shunem (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"King David"
Haggith was a wife of David. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"began to boast"
These are men who drive chariots pulled by horses.

tn.ref: fifty men to run ahead of him
tn.text: These men would go ahead of the chariots to clear the way for them and protect them.
"had never troubled him. He had never even asked him" or "had never wanted to make him angry, so he never even asked him"

tn.ref: Why have you done this or that?
tn.text: This is a rhetorical question that a father would ask to discipline his son. AT: "You should know that what you have done is wrong." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
David was the father or both Absalom and Adonijah, but they had different mothers. Absalom was born, then Adonijah.
"Adonijah discussed his plans with Joab"

tn.ref: Joab ... Zeruiah ... Abiathar ... Adonijah ... Zadok ... Benaiah ... Jehoiada ... Nathan ... Shimei ... Rei
tn.text: These are men's names. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"supported and helped Adonijah" or "promised to support and help Adonijah"
"calves that were given plenty of food so that they would be fat" or "young cows that were specially prepared for sacrifice"
This is a rocky area near Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This was the name of a spring where people got water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: all his brothers ... all the men
tn.text: This is a generalization. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: all his brothers, the king's sons
tn.text: These two phrases refer to the same people.

tn.ref: men of Judah, the king's servants
tn.text: These two phrases refer to the same people.

The purpose of this question is to introduce the information that Nathan wants to tell Bathsheba. AT: "You do not seem to have heard ... it." or "Have you heard ... it?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: that Adonijah son of Haggith has become king
tn.text: "that Haggith's son Adonijah is trying to become king"
Adonijah's mother and a wife of David. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The prophet Nathan continues to speak to Bathsheba.

tn.ref: did you not swear to your servant ... throne?
tn.text: The purpose of this question was to remind David of what he had promised Bathsheba. AT: "you swore to your servant ... throne." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Bathsheba speaks to David as if she were someone else to show that she respects David. AT: "to me, your servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])

tn.ref: he will sit on my throne
tn.text: Sitting on the throne is a metonym for being king. AT: "he will be king just as I was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Bathsheba was to use a question so David would pay attention. AT: "So then, Adonijah should not be reigning." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"tell him that what you have said is true"
"the room in which the king slept"
This is the young virgin that King David's servants had brought to care for him. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:03|1:3]].

tn.ref: bowed and prostrated herself before the king
tn.text: "bowed close to the ground in front of the king"
"What can I do for you?"
The form of "you" here is emphatic. AT: "you yourself swore to"
Bathsheba speaks as if she were another person to show David that she respects him. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:13|1:13]]. AT: "me, your servant"
This is the name of God that he revealed to his people in the Old Testament. See the translationWord page about Yahweh concerning how to translate this.

tn.ref: he shall sit on my throne
tn.text: Sitting on the throne is a metonym for being king. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:13|1:13]]. AT: "he will be king just as I was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Bathsheba continues speaking to King David.
"pay attention to what I am about to tell you"

tn.ref: oxen, fatted calves, and sheep in abundance
tn.text: "many oxen, fatted calves, and sheep"
Bathsheba continues to speak to King David.

tn.ref: the eyes of all Israel are on you
tn.text: Here "eyes" refers to the people. This is a generalization. AT: "all the people of Israel are watching you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Sitting on the throne is a metonym for being king. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:13|1:13]]. AT: "will be king"

tn.ref: when my master the king sleeps with his fathers
tn.text: Bathsheba speaks to King David as if she were speaking about him to show that she respects him. AT: "when you sleep with your fathers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])
This is a polite way of saying "dies." (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: I and my son Solomon will be regarded as criminals
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "the new king will regard my son Solomon and me as criminals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Nathan the prophet speaks to King David.
"bowed very low"
Nathan the prophet continues to speak to King David.

tn.ref: have you said, 'Adonijah will reign after me, and he will sit on my throne?'
tn.text: This can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "have you said that Adonijah will reign after you, and he will sit on your throne?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: he will sit on my throne
tn.text: Sitting on the throne is a metonym for being king. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:13|1:13]]. AT: "he will be king just as I was"

Adonijah probably sat at a table where he could watch all those he had invited as they ate and drank. The main idea is that the people Nathan named were with Adonijah and they were celebrating together. AT: "eating and drinking with him" or "eating and drinking where he can see them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Nathan the prophet continues to speak to King David.

tn.ref: Has my master the king done this without telling us, your servants, who should sit on the throne after him?
tn.text: Nathan refers to David in the third person. This is a way of showing respect to the king. It can be stated in second person. AT: "Have you, my master the king, done this without telling us, your servants, who should sit on the throne after you?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: who should sit on the throne
tn.text: Sitting on the throne is a metonym for being king. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:13|1:13]]. AT: "who would be king after him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
King David makes a promise to Bathsheba.
"came before the king" or "came back to the king"
"made a solemn promise"

tn.ref: he will sit on my throne in my place
tn.text: Sitting on the throne is a metonym for being king. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:13|1:13]]. AT: "he will take my place and be king just as I was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: May my master King David live forever
tn.text: Bathsheba knew David would not live forever; this is a way of saying that he is a good king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
King David anoints Solomon king.
David speaks of himself as if he were speaking of someone else so Zadok, Nathan, and Benaiah would remember that David is still king. AT: "my servants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])
This is the name of a water spring. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
King David continues to speak on behalf of Solomon as the one who will become king.

tn.ref: he will come and sit on my throne
tn.text: The words "sit on the throne" are used as a metonym for being king in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:13|1:13]], [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:15|1:17]], and [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:28|1:30]]. Here David speaks of Solomon literally sitting on a physical throne.
They agree and will do what King David said.

tn.ref: May Yahweh, the God of my master the king, confirm
tn.text: Benaiah speaks to King David as if he were speaking to someone else to show that he respects King David. AT: "My master and king, may Yahweh your God confirm" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])

tn.ref: has been with my master the king, so
tn.text: Benaiah speaks to King David as if he were speaking to someone else to show that he respects King David. AT: "has been with you, my master the king, so" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])

tn.ref: make his throne greater than the throne of my master King David
tn.text: The word "throne" is a metonym for either 1) the person who sits on the throne. AT: "make the one who sits on the throne greater than my master King David" or 2) the kingdom over which the one who sits on the throne rules. AT: "make his kingdom greater than the kingdom of my master King David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the throne of my master King David
tn.text: Benaiah speaks to King David as if he were speaking to someone else to show that he respects King David. AT: "your throne, my master King David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])
The people of Israel anoint Solomon as king over Israel.
These are names of people groups. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a spring, where fresh water comes out of the ground. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: took the horn of oil out of the tent
tn.text: This means the priest took the special animal horn filled with olive oil that was kept in Yahweh's special tent.
Possible meanings are 1) the horn of an animal filled with olive oil or 2) a container that had replaced the original horn, but the people still called it a horn. AT: "took a container of oil"
This is a generalization. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Adonijah hears the loud noise and waits for the news.
Adonijah learns that Solomon is the new king.
These are names of people groups. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Jonathan continues to speak to Adonijah about Solomon.

tn.ref: is sitting on the throne of the kingdom
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) that these words are a metonym for being king. AT: "is now king" or 2) that Solomon was physically sitting on the physical throne. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:35|1:35]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: a person to sit on my throne this day
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) that these words are a metonym for being king. AT: "a person to be king today as I was" or 2) that Solomon was physically sitting on the physical throne. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:35|1:35]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Adonijah becomes terrified of King Solomon.
Another possible meaning is "They began to act quickly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Adonijah ... took hold of the horns of the altar
tn.text: The "horns of the altar" symbolized the strength and protection of Yahweh, but because Adonijah literally went into the area of the physical tent to take literal hold of the physical horns, you should translate this literally.
Another possible meaning is "Adonijah ... quickly went" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The servants speak to King Solomon as if they were speaking of someone else to show that they respected King Solomon. AT: "is afraid of you, King Solomon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])

tn.ref: he will not kill his servant
tn.text: Adonijah speaks of himself as if he were speaking of another person so people will think that he respects King Solomon. AT: "he will not kill me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])
Solomon spares the life of Adonijah.

tn.ref: not a hair of his will fall to the earth
tn.text: This is an exaggeration to say that Solomon will keep Adonijah safe. AT: "not a hair of his head will fall" or "I will keep him safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

The abstract noun "wickedness" can be translated as a verb. It is spoken of as if it were an object that could be found in a container. This can be translated in active form. AT: "he does what is evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
